importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The couple began their relationship in the summer of 2004, after Britney Spears's commercial peak, marking the start of a high-profile relationship that later became public and controversial.
Britney Spears filed for divorce in 2006, beginning a period of public and private conflict that included custody battles and public scrutiny of her mental health and behavior.
The divorce was finalized in 2007, officially ending the marital relationship and leading to a legal and public power struggle over the custody of their children.
A temporary conservatorship was established in 2008 due to public incidents involving Britney Spears, later made permanent and remaining in effect until 2021.
The conservatorship was lifted in 2021, allowing Britney Spears to regain full control over her life and custody of her children.
The memoir by Kevin Federline, titled 'You Thought You Knew,' was released on Tuesday, 2025-10-20, sparking renewed public debate about Spears's mental health, parenting, and relationship dynamics.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year period from 2004 to 2007, during which the couple were together, married, and divorced, represents the central timeline of their relationship and its subsequent public fallout.

The period from 2008 to 2021, during which Spears was under conservatorship, highlights the long-term legal and social implications of her mental health and parenting behavior, which remain central to public discourse.

The current timeframe, marked by the release of Federline's memoir, represents the resurgence of a high-profile public debate about Spears's personal life and mental health, reigniting media attention and legal and social scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: Kevin Federline's memoir, 'You Thought You Knew,' alleges that Britney Spears exhibited erratic behavior as a mother and wife, including substance use during pregnancy and threatening behavior toward her sons.
Federline claims Spears drank during pregnancy and used cocaine while breastfeeding, which she has denied, and alleges that her sons were afraid of her during adolescence.
The book suggests that Spears's public behavior—such as shaving her head and hitting a photographer's car—raised concerns about her mental health and led to a long-term conservatorship.
The conservatorship, established in 2008 and lasting until 2021, was enforced by her father and others, with Spears regaining custody of her children after its termination.

Britney Spears has publicly criticized the memoir, accusing Federline of exploiting their relationship to profit and portraying her as out of control, while maintaining that she has always prioritized her children’s well-being.
Federline claims he wrote the book after years of hesitation, to share the truth about their relationship and to ensure his children understand the full story.
The book's release in 2025 reignites public debate about Spears’s mental health, parenting, and the role of conservatorship in protecting vulnerable individuals.

namedEntities.name: Kevin Federline
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former husband of Britney Spears; author of the memoir 'You Thought You Knew'; claims to have concerns about Spears’s mental health and parenting behavior; has publicly accused her of substance abuse and erratic behavior.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kevin Federline is central to the article as the author of a new memoir that offers a critical perspective on Britney Spears's personal and domestic life, sparking public controversy.

namedEntities.name: Britney Spears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pop star and former spouse of Kevin Federline; accused in the memoir of erratic behavior, substance abuse during pregnancy, and threatening actions toward her children; has publicly criticized the book and defended her relationship with her sons.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Britney Spears is the primary figure of controversy in the article, as her past behavior and mental health are being re-evaluated through the lens of Federline's allegations and her own public response.

namedEntities.name: Preston Spears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of Britney Spears's sons, born during the couple’s marriage; currently 20 years old; given full custody by Federline after the divorce.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Preston is a key figure in the custody and parenting disputes, with Federline alleging that Spears was threatening to him and his brother during childhood.

namedEntities.name: Jayden Spears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of Britney Spears's sons, born during the couple’s marriage; currently 19 years old; given full custody by Federline after the divorce.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jayden is also central to the custody and parenting narrative, with Federline alleging that he and his brother were afraid of Spears during adolescence.

namedEntities.name: Conservatorship
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal arrangement under which a third party manages aspects of Britney Spears's life, including finances and medical decisions; established in 2008 and lasted until 2021.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The conservatorship is a critical element in the article, representing a long-term legal and social intervention into Spears’s personal life due to public concerns about her mental health and parenting.

namedEntities.name: Free Britney Movement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A public movement advocating for the removal of the conservatorship and greater autonomy for Britney Spears; Federline claims he does not fully support it.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The movement is referenced in the context of public debate about Spears's autonomy and the legitimacy of legal oversight, which Federline disputes.

namedEntities.name: You Thought You Knew
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The memoir written by Kevin Federline, published on 2025-10-20, detailing allegations against Britney Spears’s behavior as a mother and wife.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This book is the central piece of information in the article, serving as the source of the allegations and public controversy.

namedEntities.name: The Woman in Me
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Britney Spears's memoir, released prior to Federline's book, in which she accuses Federline of portraying her as out of control.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Spears's memoir is referenced as a counter-narrative to Federline's claims, highlighting the mutual accusations and public rivalry between the two.

namedEntities.name: BBC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Media outlet that obtained and shared excerpts from Federline's memoir ahead of its publication.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The BBC played a role in disseminating information from the memoir, contributing to the public awareness and media coverage of the controversy.

namedEntities.name: Listenin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Publisher of Kevin Federline's memoir 'You Thought You Knew'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Listenin is the publisher responsible for the formal release of the memoir, marking its official entry into the public domain.

namedEntities.name: Associated Press
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Media outlet that reported on Federline’s motivations for writing the book and his reflections on fatherhood and truth.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AP provided context on Federline's personal motivations, adding depth to the narrative behind the book's publication.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kevin Federline, the former husband of pop star Britney Spears, has released a memoir titled 'You Thought You Knew,' in which he alleges that Spears exhibited erratic behavior as a mother and wife, including drinking during pregnancy and using cocaine while breastfeeding. He claims that her sons were afraid of her during adolescence, with accounts of her standing silently in their room with a knife. These allegations come as Spears has publicly condemned the book, accusing Federline of exploiting their relationship to profit and portraying her as out of control. A conservatorship, established in 2008 and lasting until 2021, was a result of public incidents involving Spears, and she has maintained that she always prioritized her children's well-being. The memoir, released on 2025-10-20, reignites a long-standing public debate about Spears's mental health, parenting, and the role of legal oversight in her life, with both parties presenting conflicting narratives.
title: What does Kevin Federline's upcoming book say about Britney Spears?
